raw_text:
Wenger keeping faith with Almunia
 
 Arsene Wenger has pledged to keep faith with stand-in keeper Manuel Almunia for the crunch week which could define Arsenal's season.
 
 Almunia will start Tuesday's Champions League group tie against Rosenborg and is likely to face Chelsea on Sunday. Wenger said: "You don't think I would take out one goalkeeper for just one game, do you? I don't do that. "I have to give him a run for a few games. It's just that I don't want to make this story bigger than it is." Wenger insists he has complete faith in the 27-year-old Spaniard, who was signed last summer from Celta Vigo as back-up to Jens Lehmann.
 
 "If you look at my career, you will see that I have left many big players out for a long time. I've done it with Dennis Bergkamp, Kanu, everybody. "It's because it's a goalkeeper, that's all. It's a usual situation for me. You put your best team out, no matter who it is. "For me, it was not a big mistake at Old Trafford and I wasn't alarmed by what happened against Birmingham either. "It's nothing against Lehmann. I think he's a great keeper, as is Almunia. You can only play one of them. "These people are not robots - they have good periods and less good periods. Just because Lehmann doesn't play for two or three weeks, or longer or shorter, it doesn't mean I've lost faith in him."
 
 But former Arsenal keeper David Seaman believes Lehmann has been harshly treated. Seaman told the Daily Mail: "Jens is a fantastic keeper. He deserves another chance. "He has made a few mistakes but on form he deserves to be the first-team choice." With Arsenal hit by injuries and suspension, inexperienced midfield pair of Mathieu Flamini and Cesc Fabregas will line up against Rosenborg but Wenger is confident they will prove more than capable. "It puts a lot of pressure on them but it's a good learning process," said Wenger. "I'm not worried as they are both mentally strong and will put in the needed workrate."
 
 The Gunners go into the game boosted by the news that defender Sol Campbell is on the verge of signing a new deal with the club. And the 30-year-old, whose current contract runs out in the summer, has made it clear he is determined to achieve Champions League success with Arsenal. Campbell said: "It means a lot to me to go through, it's everything. We want to carry on in this competition. "That's where the best teams in Europe are. To be in there, playing against these guys and trying to win the trophy, is the first thing in my mind."
 
 Meanwhile, Thierry Henry believes he will be blamed if Arsenal fail to qualify for the next stage of the Champions League. Henry will captain the side in place of the suspended Patrick Vieira as the Gunners seek the required victory over Rosenborg. And the striker said: "If we don't win and we go out of the competition, like it or not, it's going to be my fault. That's the way it is. "If the team don't win I know I will be criticised, no matter how I play."
llama3.2:1b: Arsene Wenger has stated that he will keep faith with stand-in goalkeeper Manuel Almunia for the upcoming Champions League matches despite having the option to replace him with Jens Lehmann. Wenger believes Almunia is a good backup and has complete confidence in his ability to perform under pressure. Wenger also expressed concerns over the treatment of former Arsenal keeper David Seaman, who believes Jens Lehmann should be given another chance. Meanwhile, Thierry Henry will captain the team as they seek victory against Rosenborg and potentially face criticism if they fail to qualify for the next stage of the Champions League.
llama3.2:3b: Arsene Wenger has pledged to continue using Manuel Almunia as Arsenal's goalkeeper despite criticism of his decision to bench Jens Lehmann. Wenger believes that giving Almunia a run in games is essential for his development and has faith in the 27-year-old Spaniard. The team, meanwhile, faces pressure with injuries and suspensions affecting midfielders Mathieu Flamini and Cesc Fabregas, but Wenger remains confident in their abilities. Defender Sol Campbell is close to signing a new contract, while Thierry Henry believes he will be blamed if Arsenal fail to qualify for the next stage of the Champions League.
gemma2:2b: Arsene Wenger plans to keep Manuel Almunia in goal for Arsenal's crucial Champions League games against Rosenborg and Chelsea. He believes Almunia deserves a run of starts and that he has faith in the 27-year-old Spaniard despite some recent mistakes.  Former goalkeeper David Seaman disagrees with this decision, stating that Jens Lehmann deserves another chance. While there will be pressure on young midfielders Mathieu Flamini and Cesc Fabregas, Wenger believes they are up to the task. Sol Campbell is nearing a new deal at Arsenal as he seeks Champions League success. Thierry Henry will captain the team against Rosenborg in place of the suspended Patrick Vieira.  Henry anticipates facing criticism if Arsenal fail to advance in the competition.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Arsenal forward Manuel Almunia has been kept in place as a stand-in goalkeeper for the week ahead of their Champions League group tie against Rosenborg. Wenger says he doesn’t believe he is taking out one goalkeeper for just one game and adds that he will give him "a run for several games". He admits his faith was put to test by Lehmann last summer, but believes Almunia has proven himself with the transfer from Celta Vigo. Almunia made a few mistakes but Wenger says he is confident he can make a difference in this game. Arsenal have made a significant change in their midfield line-up with defender Sol Campbell on a new deal and former Arsenal keeper David Seaman thinks Lehmann deserves another chance at being the first-team choice. Thierry Henry believes Arsenal will face challenges if they fail to qualify for the Champions League next stage, while Arsenal captain Thomas Hogg claims he will play his part in the game if they don't win.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Arsene Wenger pledges faith in Arsenal backup goalkeeper Manuel Almunia for key Champions League matches, despite concerns about his playing time and past performances. Former player David Seaman defends Jens Lehmann's form while Arsenal faces injury-hit opponents, but Thierry Henry admits he could be blamed if the club misses out on European qualification.
qwen2.5:3b: Arsene Wenger has vowed to keep Manuel Almunia as Arsenal’s backup keeper for a crucial week including Tuesday's Champions League match against Rosenborg and Sunday's clash with Chelsea. Despite concerns over Lehmann’s form, Wenger insists he trusts Almunia fully. Former keeper David Seaman criticizes Lehmann's treatment. Arsenal faces significant injury and suspension issues but Wenger is confident in Mathieu Flamini and Cesc Fabregas. Defender Sol Campbell is nearing a new contract that includes Champions League success ambitions. Thierry Henry will lead the team, accepting responsibility for potential failure in qualifying if Arsenal loses to Rosenborg.

The Gunners are strong, overcoming injuries and uncertain suspensions while facing new additions like Thierry Henry.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Arsenal manager, Arwe Weingar, has announced that he will stick with Manuel Almunia in the crucial Champions League match against Rosenborg. Weingar emphasized that Almunia should get a chance to showcase his quality for the club after losing him out for just one game during their last fixture. However, the manager is not worried about the injury and suspension of Mathieu Flamini and Cesc Fabregas in Arsenal's midfield. Weingar believes that Almunia deserves a chance to prove himself and will be a mentally strong player when he returns from his injury. As for Sol Campbell, the Gunner defender has made it clear that he wants to stay with the club and win the Champions League in future seasons. This goal is not only important for him but also for the team's overall success. Meanwhile, Arwe Henry believes that if Arsenal don't qualify for the next round, it would be unfair of him to blame him or the suspended Patrick Vieira.

Meanwhile, Thierry Henry has assured that he will not be blamed if Arsenal fails to qualify for the next stage of the Champions League.

Meanwhile, Thierry Henry believes he will face criticism if Arsenal fail to qualify for the next stage of the competition.

Despite concerns about Jens Lehmann's inconsistent form, Wenger maintains faith in both goalkeepers, emphasizing that they are not robots and have good periods followed by less so. Former Arsenal keeper David Seaman disagrees, arguing that Lehmann deserves another chance as a first-team choice due to his fantastic form.

Thierry Henry, set to captain the team due to Patrick Vieira's suspension, acknowledges personal accountability for Arsenal's qualification status. If the team fails to advance in the competition, he anticipates facing criticism, regardless of his performance.
